But those hoping to relive their childhood for a couple hours, and maybe introduce their little on to it, might find a lot of heart and a silly fun time to be had.

I grew up watching Power Rangers and I have been waiting for a film as good as this. For us old schoolers it is surely a great trip down Nostalgia lane. Also for new viewers I'd say that it is a great choice in film. Power Rangers, a few cuss words and Bryan Cranston... what more do you need. It's finally grown up and they have done a great job of doing just that.
Cast are funny and fit the roles perfectly... all in all I could have given it a higher grade but a 7 is reasonable but probably closer to an 8
It could be better, yes it could, but is a different way to see the Power Rangers. But still is very entertaining, even for the original tv version viewers.

A well tried attempt to cling to the nostalgia of the TV shows. Saban's Power Rangers offers what could be a fantastic retelling of the story that is, unfortunately, muddled down by poor pacing, oddly forced character development and cheesy references to its predecessor. While it does tease more, offering information for a sequel, let's hope that the DVD of this retelling offers more in a different cut.

Review title: Almost hated because of the shaky cam!
Review_body: The cast was good, young superheroes, liked that. Storyline is pretty good too. The VFX isn't like what i've expected but not bad. Although, I almost fall in love with Becky G! LOL! Almost hated because of shaky the cam! I don't know why movie producers does things like that. It takes my eye out. I've got eye problems because of that!

Review title: Oh, I Really Wanted this to be Decent
Review_body: I was a fan of the show in the nineties; I found it extremely entertaining because of its simplicity and goofiness. I enjoyed the 1995 film for the same reasons, and the likability of the cast. So, I wanted this movie to, at least, be entertaining. It was not. The characters were bland, uninteresting, and unlikable. The costumes, so to speak, looking terrible, and exactly what you'd expect from people attempting to update a campy 90's show. There wasn't a single character to whom people could relate in the whole movie. If anything, the experience was exhausting and infuriating. Picture the Transformers movie with WORSE effects and even less likable characters. Do yourself a favor; do no go see this bland, useless nonsense.
This could have been the coolest reboot in history. The writing was bland and cliche and the design was too "shiny" and smooth. Not much else to say other than I was bored.

When the original series aired I was 5, and 10 when it ended. This is exactly the movie I wanted to see. The movie spends the time developing the characters and the relevance of the Power Rangers. Elizabeth banks is brilliant and genuinely terrifying. Zordon finally has some gravity and personality rather than being a 2 dimensional floating head. There's a reviewer complaining about the sexualisation; which I find ridiculous, as we have all been teenagers and most of that time is spent affirming our sexuality. The squeaky clean version of the characters from the series would not have been believable in our modern age nor entertaining. I urge all the fans to go see this and at least keep an open mind.
Nice improvement too the original and original on it self.

Review title: It's not like the 90s kids show... and that is a good thing!
Review_body: Before I begin, I must tell you one of the biggest spoilers of this movie. IT'S NOT LIKE THE TV SHOW FROM THE 90s! If you grew up watching it like I did, this will be a little different than the one our generation grew up with. Trust me when I tell you, that's a good thing. Imagine if Batman movies still had the likeness of Adam West's portrayal of Batman from the 60s! It would be lame and people would get sick of it! That being said, let's dive in!THE TV SHOW VS THE MOVIE This movie still has the core values that make up the lore of the Power Rangers: They still morph. They still have to join forces as a team to stop evil. They still need to call on their Zords when they need more power. Rita is still out to destroy the world and take over. Goldar makes an appearance, but he doesn't speak.The things that separate this movie from the TV show are: They don't have fighting skills starting out; they have to train. They are given super powers like strength and speed that let them punch harder, jump higher and so on. They can't morph at first because they don't have the skill to do so. They need to draw the power out that exist inside of them. Zordon even makes them feel bad about it by saying "If you can't morph, you aren't rangers." What a jerk! LOLTHE PLOT The movie opens up with Zordon (Bryan Cranston) fighting Rita, and losing. In his last attempt to stop her, he knocks her into the ocean and she is in a state of hibernation until present day. Zordon, with his last breaths, seals away the power coins, or rocks if you'd prefer, for a future team of rangers to find. Skip ahead to present day and you see Jason, Kimberly, and Billy all in Saturday morning detention. They all made mistakes, and they all are paying for it. They eventually meet the other two members of the team, Zack and Trini at a digging site. Billy's father died and I assume he was a scientist of some sort. Billy has a fascination with rocks and blows into some rocks and the team discovers the power crystals. When he blew the rocks that exposed the crystals, security forces were called in to find out who was playing around with explosives. The team escapes in Billy's mother's minivan. As they approach a train crossing they attempt to make it but don't. Oddly, they all wake up at home but notice they have powers. They all meet up at the site again and find the secret lair to Zordon's fortress. They encounter Alpha-5 (BTW HE DOES SAY "AYE, YI, YI, YI, YI!" He says it once, and it's not annoying!) They are introduced to Zordon's essence; which is another way of saying the original Zordon is gone, but he can still come back. Zordon wants the new rangers to help him come back, but to do that, they need to prove they are capable of morphing. Morphing, apparently comes from the inside out. It sounds cheesy, but it looks awesome! The group cannot do it and so, Zordon makes them train without armor. They get the snot beaten out of them! It makes it more realistic from the viewer's standpoint. They didn't ask for this, they didn't want this, they are just kinda rolling with it, and they eventually earn the role. (It reminds me of Spider-man, the Toby McGuire films.) They were gifted powers they don't know how to use because they never had them before. It makes you want to see them toughen up and grow as super heroes! After going through that process, Alpha-5 shows them the Zords "when you're ready, you will pilot these," he tells them. Zack can't wait, and he steals one and drives it, horribly. Later that night, Rita visits Trini at home and threatens to kill her if she doesn't tell Rita where the Zeo Crystals are. Rita mocks Trini because she cannot morph, and then offers her to join Rita against Zordon. She gives her an ultimatum, and requests that she meet her to make her decision. Rita threatens that "tomorrow I will destroy your city." Trini meets with the other rangers and tells them about the encounter. They meet Rita and try to fight her without armor and get their butts handed to them. She kills Billy after finding out from him, where the crystals are located. The team take Billy to Zordon and then, because of their efforts, acting as real rangers, Zordon can return. He doesn't. He uses that power to bring Billy back to life. The rangers morph and then head out to stop Rita. They use their skills and armor to beat down Putties, and eventually call on their Zords. They stop Rita by combining their Zords. When they defeat Rita, she tells the rangers that "others will come, it won't be just me!" (I hope she means Lord Zed!). Jason asks her to give up her power crystal and staff, and surrender to Zordon. She refuses, and they literally B!@CH SLAP her into space. As she ascends into space, she hibernates again, turning to ice.FINAL THOUGHTS This movie is nothing like the TV show I grew up with in the 90s. I have fond memories of that show from when I was a kid, but it matured. For that I am thankful! It was fun to watch, and it brought the little kid inside of me out. My kids loved it, and I can certainly say it exceeded my expectations! It's not like the show I remembered, but that's okay. It's actually better IMHO. BTW, there were two rangers from the TV show that cameoed towards the end. I won't spoil that for you! 😉

Review title: Movie captures true power of friendship and Power rangers NO SPOILERS
Review_body: True fans of the TV show like myself, they gonna love this movie. It has everything that power rangers movie suppose to have: Great story, zords, megazord, evil Rita Repulsa. O man, its like going in childhood all over again. If you expect a lot of action and non - stoping killing and overacting, this movie is not for you. One of the best Power Ranger movies so far!

There's absolutely NO WAY I'm taking my children to watch this! I highly recommend lcocsj's review as to why this is NOT a kid-friendly movie. I'm glad I saw it alone first.I get that heroes are usually flawed, imperfect people. But being flawed/imperfect is not the same as deliberately being just,... bad. These 'heroes' are bad, and not in a good way. I would love to spell it all out, but I'll spare the spoilers.In spite of the above, this might actually have been a decent movie (as long as you're not taking young children to see it, because you'll have a lot of explaining to do to them afterward), but the dialog is so horrendous, it seems like a fifth grader wrote it.

Review title: Amazing affects, gave me goosebumps as a coming back childhood memory
Review_body: The graphic is absolutely astounding. Although the plot is quite loose, it does connect to the origin series that all characters are built formerly based on their personalities. Definitely bring the chill to all those 90s kids when they appear first in their morphing form and especially spectacular super hero landing right there!

As the parent of a son on the Autism spectrum (ASD) I could not be more furious at the irresponsible way they have portrayed people on the spectrum in this ridiculous movie. How many people will come away from this movie thinking they now know what a person on the spectrum is like? Because he lined up some pencils? Because he said "stop hugging me now"? Sheldon from Big Bang, Shaun from The Good Doctor...if they can show ASD properly you could have, too.You had an incredible opportunity to show inclusivity for people with real traits, but you squandered it. Even worse though, while shows like BBT and TGD make real efforts to show significant traits so that the general public might come away with some idea of the real life issues ASD people contend with, you instead marginalized it and trivialized it.On top of all this, many of your hardcore fans are on the spectrum. Shame on you. I'm very grateful my son went the Transformers route so he would not have been let down but your utter disregard for people with this disorder. As an aside, my 20 y/o ASD son, who personally connects with Sheldon but to a much higher degree with Shaun, watched this movie recently. I asked him what he thought of how they portrayed a person on the spectrum, his reply, "There was an Autistic person in the movie? I must have missed that part."Well done. Really, hats off to you for showing a huge amount of social irresponsibility. Don't be proud of this.

Review title: Nothing for Nostalgia, Nothing for Entertainment
Review_body: Who is this movie made for? Is it for someone like me in his late 20s-early 30's, a long-time Power Rangers fan, and someone who grew up on the original Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers? No. The only thing that nods it's head at us is a brief 1-second cameo of the original rangers at the end. There is no classic over-the-top action, no martial arts motiff, no swift and rhythmic hand gesturing, no announcement morphing (or hardly any morphing for that matter), and no cool, stellar combat scenes. Not even a flip or an extreme sports sequence. Lastly, they never played the power rangers theme song. Instead, the theme consisted of long, synthesized space riffs. It didn't fit for Power Rangers at all.Then is it for kids, a younger, new generation? No way. It's terrible. It has no plot. The characters are brash stereotypes, the dialogue is awful and it's not even kid-appropriate.Is it for action fans? Again, not a chance. This movie had maybe two minutes of fighting, I want to say. And it's not even like Wonder Woman or BvS, which were both short on fighting sequences but what they had were pretty good. The rest was....I don't know, teens trying to "find themselves", and they do that by finding each other, I guess? And becoming Power Rangers?To sum up, this movie had no right to be produced. At the pre-production phase someone should have asked: who is our audience? In fact, it's a very simple question that should have been asked by the person doing the screenplay, the director, and the producer. It could have saved a lot of agony and a classic brand and franchise from becoming a heap of garbage. The original Power Rangers didn't take itself too seriously. It was about being cool and being bad-ass, flipping around and fighting bad guys, and at the end of the day, jumping in a gigantic robot and taking part in a Godzilla-esque duel in downtown Angel Grove. This one is too touchy feely and not enough kung-pow!A proper Power Rangers reboot should have over-the-top action, classic branding, and be a tribute to the classic Power Rangers. This film has simply slapped the Power Ranger name on a terrible movie at an attempt to make money.Sad.

this is very simple, this movie was great, if you are or were a power rangers fan or just liked the show then you will love the movie, i did, they even had a go go power rangers theme moment there, this was so good, never expected Hollywood to finally succeed in adapting something. please keep them coming i want to see more.

Review title: Should've been more about Power Rangers
Review_body: It wasn't a bad movie. I liked the whole backstory they created with Zordon and Rita and this movie had interesting interpretations of them. I think keeping Rita closer to the way she was on the TV show would've worked also rather than this version who was much more sinister and out to kill, but this version of Rita did work pretty well for the movie. The ranger actors were all great, and I liked that they were given more dimension than they were on the show. I liked too how they showed them becoming friends and learning to work together, when in the show they're one-dimensional and they kind of just come together out of nowhere just because they were chosen to be rangers. I do think Billy should've been more like how he was on the show though, I didn't get enough of a nerd vibe from this movie's version. Alpha 5 had a few funny lines, but I don't think Bill Hader's voice worked for him.My biggest issue with the movie is that it was too much about the civilian teens and there wasn't enough Power Rangers action. Far too much of the movie is about the rangers as civilians, and they only morph an hour and a half into the movie. There should have been some battles against some of the show's classic monsters leading up to the big one against Goldar and Rita. Instead they go right to big battle, and even that it doesn't last long enough. They go from struggling to control the Megazord to destroying Goldar and sending Rita into space. Overall I will say it's a decent movie, but it needed to have more... Power Rangers in it. It should've been a little closer to the show, should've had more morphed action. The Power Rangers loving kid in me is pretty disappointed, but it was a good enough effort to turn the franchise into a big budget superhero movie with more character depth set in today's world.

Review title: Not as good as it should have been.
Review_body: You can easily skip first 1:30h of the movie because of typical teenage movie drama. Morphing comes really late in the movie, almost till the end of it. Bryan Cranston did a great job as always. Morphing was fresh looking - animation wise and that's all good I could find. For a 100 million budget movie, it should have looked way better. Actors are still green at best. I must say that old school Power rangers are still better than these ones.

Review title: Go Go to your local Cinema.
Review_body: Power Rangers isn't a ground-breaker in the superhero genre. But in an era of Hollywood rebooting properties from our past, most of which being plain and lackluster, it shifted my expectations into turbo, coming off as a heartfelt and fun surprise. The best part about this reboot of the cheesy 90's phenomenon is that it adds more depth to the lore and characters of its franchise. Dean Israelite, who previously directed the indie sci-fi flick, Project Almanac, managed to add his greatest strength to the rangers; making their personalities and situations more believable and realistic. Each of them are misfits, having their own little quirks and stories that they must venture through to become the team they were meant to be. The solid acting from the main cast helps as well, with additional shout-outs to the hammy and deliciously evil Elizabeth Banks and goofy Bill Hader.I'm also appreciative of the film's tone. Some say it's uneven, and while there are some unexpectedly dark moments in the film (most involving Rita, who is more of a threat this time around), there's still plenty of chuckle-worthy moments of humor and fun. A lot better than just being dumb or overly dark/gritty. My only real complaint is that the film doesn't fully embrace Power Rangers' silliness at times. Some of the fan-service (like the original theme) is neat, but other times, it can feel forced in for the sake of it. The Rangers don't morph until the last act of the film, a move that I'm not particularly angry about since it feels earned, but I can imagine some would be really bothered by this. It doesn't help that, aside from a few moments here and there, the action sequence between the Rangers and Rita's fleet can go into Transformers-levels of mindless CGI sewage.Aside from that, I believe that Power Rangers is a fun time at worst, and a surprisingly good superhero origin at best. I'm having a hard time believing that I'm saying this to a Power Rangers movie, but times change, I suppose.P.S. There's a massive plug in this movie for Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, so much so that it's integral to the film's plot. I was amused by it, since it at least felt like they made fun of it while doing the whole product placement job, rather than cynically placing it in the background. Others, however, may not feel that way.

Cameo spoiler: I had zero expectations going in; the original was campy with terrible costumes, so it couldn't get worse, right?! I was pleasantly surprised at how decent it really was! My 6 year old adored it and now he's all about Power Rangers again. While I thought the actual Power Rangers costumes were a little weird (what's up with the butt cheeks?), I liked the cast and was very surprised that Jason and Kimberly had accents in real life. I also LOVED seeing the original Kimberly and Tommy at the end!

Deadset Joke of a FIlm -Discount Zac Efron -Token Asian / Black Guy - -Beastiality joke in the first scene ? Family Movie you say ?-The Screenplay is awful, the cringe is so bad -Camera Angles that don'tmake sense rushed and always shaky-Terrible CGI for 2017 -At least put some Nostalgia in to save the move, but no, it puts in the theme for 3 seconds while they run across a field in their zords - Blue Ranger dies from drowning when earlier in the movie he held his breath for 4 times as long in the underwater cave - Krispy Kreme is literally part of the plot, the scene where discount enchantress eats the donuts, hurt me inside -Discount High School Story, with cringey twilight level soundtrack and a girls backstory based on sending nudes ? Family Friendly ?-How Red Ranger spots his dad and then saves him while all the other civilians out there are getting roasted by molten gold, btw how are their no casualties at the end and they all just pop up CGI style and whip out there phones -Again antagonist was Enchantress 2.0 -Movie contained 5, 10+ minute montages and was basically in whole movie was basically in fastfoward except for camping scene which just the biggest plot device ever. If Hollywood pumps out a sequel to this movie, I will burn down Krispy Kreme, Duck this movie.

Review title: Nice in two parts, combined a disaster
Review_body: This film tries to combine the corny power rangers stuff (colours, ridiculous outfits and cheesy combat stuff) - which it does decently enough given the preconceptions of the franchise - with a teeny angst drama where everyone's depressed for one thing or the other - which, to be fair, it doesn't do too bad either (even if it's rather sketchy, since they need to have time for the power rangers stuff as well).The main issue is really that the combination of the two is a straight- up disaster. There's no connection at all - and basically putting two movies into a one-movie-time-frame means you don't get to develop much at all.And for sure, it doesn't help that most of the characters are cast poorly. None of the main characters are up to it (for sure, their scripts aren't helping either).

This cinematic experience will take you on a wonderful adventure, exploring great depths of character and story. With writing that never stops in its chronicle of action heroes and friendship, this is a motion picture that brings new heights to great storytelling. The dialogue will deliver you into a gripping new world with extraordinarily relatable disposition. Its has so much to offer in rich personality and wit, one cant help but enjoy such a beautiful spectacle. If you have not found the time for this respected work of art, I implore you to view it, as it is the single greatest film I have ever had the honor of observing. An achievement of this stature is one for the history books.

I went into this movie with zero expectations. I only watched Power Rangers a little bit when was younger and was never really into it, but, I got to say I was pleasantly surprised with this movie. I loved it, I think everyone involved did a very good job. There was a good mix of comedy, action, drama and even some sentimental moments. The actors all fit into their roles very well and some of them even surprised me. The cast had some well known actors/actresses such as Elizabeth Banks, Bill Vader and Bryan Cranston who all did very well in their roles. There was also a very good mix of new faces mixed in with Dacre Montgomery (who will be starring in season 2 of Stranger Things later this year.) Ludi Lin who was a very pleasant surprise. I have never heard of him before going to see this movie and now he is someone I am going to look out for in the future. Like probably most of you I have only heard some of Becky G's music but have never really given Her a second thought. When I heard she was going to be a main character in this movie I was a bit hesitant about it. I have never been happier to be proved wrong.She played the role of Trini perfectly and made her character someone that, I think, a lot of people can relate to. Naomi Scott as Kimberly was perfect casting. I loved her in Lemonade Mouth when I was younger so I was excited when I heard that she was cast in Power Rangers. She played the role of Kimberly very well and I definitely will be looking for her more in the future. Everyone did very well in their roles but to me, and I'm sure a lot of you, RJ Cyler stole the show. His portrayal of Billy was perfect. Billy was a very important character being the first superhero to be on the autism spectrum and RJ Cyler absolutely nailed it.Something that I personally am not a fan of in movies is a lot of CGI but, I got to say this movie pulled it off. It wasn't cheesy and went with the movie very well. I also have to mention the soundtrack in the film. every song fit the moment perfectly and added that extra bit to the movie. This movie was about all the characters becoming the Power Rangers and evolving. It takes a long time before they actually become the Power Rangers. The reason for doing this is to show how all of the characters develop throughout the movie which I think was a very dog move. Every character develops really well personally as well as a group. I really hope there is a sequel as the end set it up perfectly. At the end of this movie it shows the teacher at detention introduce a new character, Tommy. Introducing this character would be a good fit for the next movie (if there is one.) If they do decide to do another movie we will be able to see the rangers more experienced and, if they do decide to make Tommy a ranger, we can see how they adjust to the new addition.

Review title: An awful reboot of an already awful television show!
Review_body: Before I review the film, lets go back to the beginning of the awful television show.Mighty Morphin Power Rangers started airing on Fox Kids. Its true genesis was as an Americanized version of a long running Japanese kids show called Super Sentai which premiered back in 1975.Mighty Morphin Power Rangers (with its bad 1990s haircuts, fashion, and earrings) merged original Japanese footage from two Super Sentai shows called Zyuranger and Dairanger with absolutely horrid American footage that was a bad Saved By The Bell knock off which eventually joined Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles as the latest craze on Fox Kids. The third season, which ripped off Kakuranger, had the power rangers turned into children and replaced by "ninja" aliens. (Are you kidding me?!)Fast forward to 2017. Power Rangers has lost most of its former popularity, so greedy plagiarist Haim Saban decides to reboot "his" power rangers (which was never "his" in the first place, it belonged to Toei who originally created Super Sentai/power rangers) the same way Ninja Turtles was "rebooted" for the big screen a couple of years ago.This time, the new cast is completely dysfunctional and the first 90 minutes are a real DRAG ripping off other teen angst movies so much that many kids will undoubtedly find it BORING. (Which they did in my screening!) Its far more Chronicle/Fant4stic than power rangers.Elizabeth Banks is the only one doing decent work as the new Rita Repulsa, a former Power Ranger looking to revive her giant monster Goldar. Even Bryan Cranston is miscast and looks lost here as Zordon!The ending does finally bring the audience its goofy power rangers (in the last ten minutes!) with even more ridiculous plastic costumes than the cheesy Zyuranger spandex on the old show and bargain basement, combining video game CGI visual effects for the end battle which really DOES looks like another Playstation 2 game.The word CHEESE cannot describe how eye rolling and preposterous the ending is. (A megazord slap into outer space PUL-EEZZE)!Not to mention the endless Krispy Kreme references/placements are downright embarrassing.Do the world a favor watch a far superior comic book movie like Logan instead and save your money!Power rangers was a HUGE disappointment, its poor box office worldwide proves it. (A sequel is VERY unlikely now!)A one on a scale of 1-10.Power Rangers is another box office BOMB for Lionsgate, which was on a roll after the great John Wick sequel.

Review title: Hey awesome movie good actors in the movie
Review_body: Hey i just saw the power rangers film it very good i really enjoyed the film i remember the original series when it was mighty morphing power rangers it was good to see the rangers back on the big screen i hope they do a second film I was very amazed at the film i liked it was very clean film they were awesome with it i like the new suites it was neat rita looked awesome but goldaer was different i like the original goldare i liked how they showed what zordon looked like i cant waite till it comes out on DVD and Blu-ray Go go power rangers

The thing I found the most annoying about this movie was the fact that even after being a big budget movie the CGI was worse than I could have ever imagined. The big baddie at the end and the megazod looked more like old video game characters.However, it is not just the CGI. It seemed like the writers and director just wanted to cash in on the name and didn't work at all on the script as well as acting. The rangers were plain bad actors portraying mediocre acting skills at best. The script was floozy and it is only after the entry of Rita Repulsa (Elizabeth Banks) that I thought that maybe this movie will turn out to be good.The film takes too much time to build up and we have to sit through the bad acting, boring dialogues and what appears to be The Breakfast Club reunion. The middle parts feel good at some points but are too dragged out for the viewer to care. Although there are some effective scenes but they are not enough to save the whole movie. The rangers spend at max 10 minutes in their suits after which the zords come into play. The last half hour which should have been explosive action (think Transformers) was dialed down to a stupid fight which didn't seem as threatening as they wanted us to feel.The only saving grace come at the start of the movie which I should say hyped me for a real bad movie. Elizabeth Banks shines in the beginning but seems to be over acting for the rest of the movie. It also doesn't help when your villain isn't seen fighting in the end and is just seen as a moot spectator.In my opinion, Power Rangers is what Transformers would have been if it had the bad CGI. The movie battled between being darker and grittier while simultaneously trying to be like the old power rangers. An amateur cast, the bad CGI and the lousy script make up for a really bad movie experience.

I went into power rangers with rather mediocre expectation and was blown away by how clever this movie is. It is exactly the right blend of fun and exciting, while being dark and challenging at the same time. It is also LITTERED with fan bait with original theme song and all. Absolutely loved this movie and will be seeing it again before it leaves cinemas. Hoping it makes enough money to warrant sequels (opening weekend suggests it will) because they have such a good grounding here to just go to town on all the sequels (7 as reported earlier) they have planned. 9/10 for me.

It's not a perfect film, but the rating is so low for this, that it needs tobe bumped up! I grew up with the low budget original. Where every single episode was formulaic and the characters were 1-dimensional. They fixed a lot in this movie, making the Rangers powerful and keeping it funny at the same time! I think it's Patton Oswalt that does the voice of Zordon's helper robotand they kept the Aieee aie yaie yaie yie (spell? Lol). They kept all that was good and got rid of what was bad, and even poked fun of it, in the reboot. I need like two more sequels, please!

Review title: It was a great movie all around
Review_body: For a guy born in the late 90's I caught the tail end of the original Mighty Morphin Power Rangers, I've seen it all by now and I have to say this movie does a great job representing the original feeling it gave me as a kid. It also had really deep character moments and so much amazing character growth. The representation of both the autistic spectrum and the LGBTQ spectrum was beautiful and suited the rangers great. The Rangers have always been diverse and now it's in more than just race. The costumes were amazing and the zords were even cooler. If I had to gripe about anything it's the way the rangers were inside the megazord but I can live with that no problem. Seeing what they did with Rita was pure gold and the two cameos in this film was fan service at its best. They felt like power rangers and the way the movie made it fit in with the times was perfect. I want to go back for more of this movie, can't wait for the sequel!

Review title: Great start for the new generation of power rangers
Review_body: I have to say I was looking forward to this movie ever since it was announced and it met up to the expectation I had. The acting from MOST of the cast was extremely good and they had some passion which payed off on there part. The movie had humour and it had familiarity to the rangers. As they are all misfits it gave them more of an edge which made you connect more to them and it just worked well. The cgi on parts wasn't all so great though, it was like watching scenes from gods of Egypt it was that bad but some scenes where OK and it wasn't that bothering. The biggest disappointment was Elizabeth banks. She should not of Been cast for the part of Rita as she fetched way too much cheese to the role. she lacked the passion in here role and it felt like she was just doing the film for a quick buck. Sometimes comedy actors do play good villains and sometimes they just fail tremendously and she failed. The end verdict is go see it as it is worth a cheeky one time watch.

Vibration, shaking and very blurry), actress (Kimberly? What happen with you? Complexity? No, Show off? No, Look pitiful? No, no, no), and last thing, a slim-Optimus Prime? Bump, I lost my interested because a slim-Optimus Prime.

Review title: Spoiler Free Review: SABANS' POWER RANGERS (2017)
Review_body: SPOILER FREE REVIEW: 25/04/2017 SABANS' POWER RANGERS (2017) I thought I would get this off my chest while it is still fresh and imprinted in the memory. Last night I was lucky enough to see the newest installment of the Power Rangers phenomenon with some close friends and better company. I proceeded to purchase my tickets online and book my spot in the cinema (as I usually do), boy I'm glad I did that as good seating was hard to find. I represented my strong liking to the franchise by wearing a custom made Red Ranger tee and even brought with me my Legacy Red Ranger helmet and Morpher. Enough about the lead up and its proceedings, now to the movie...Before watching a film like this, with such a large and multicultural fan base you can't help but have preconceived opinions and thoughts. Director Dean Israelite, who previously directed "Project Almanac" chose to go with a cast that didn't necessarily have the major Hollywood power compared to your Marvel or DC Films.Did this work? Would a well-known Hollywood actor suit the role better? Simply put, no.I think that the young, fairly inexperienced cast of Power Rangers worked extremely well together and were one of the key highlights to this movie. Dacre Montgomery (Jason Lee Scott, Red Ranger), Naomi Scott (Kimberly Hart, Pink Ranger), RJ Cyler (Billy Cranston, Blue Ranger), Ludi Lin (Zack Taylor, Black Ranger) and Becky G (Trini Kwan, Yellow Ranger) almost seemed to possess that misfit persona that seemingly worked for the movie's plot. Each of them has a different personality and this is shown by their corresponding Ranger colour. The manner in which the cast plays off one another feels almost natural, to see on the big screen and after a rocky start, they soon become a family.The movie does provide a viewer a slight backstory on the lore of Power Rangers, their wise and selfless mentor, Zordon (played by Brian Cranston), the everlasting evil and manipulative Rita Repulsa (played by Elizabeth Banks). This ensured that if you were watching Power Rangers for the first time (apart from the endless catalogue of TV series that exist) then you were catered for.Director Israelite spent a fair chunk of the movie working on the Rangers' relationship with one another and their connection to the Power Coins (the colour coins that grant them power) and the Morphing Grid (the process in which they Morph into their warriors). This was definitely done so that viewers, new to the franchise would be caught up and can enjoy the rest of the film.Once the movie did move on to the villain development and the Morphtastic fighting sequences, it felt kind of rushed, especially the last stanza between the Rangers and Goldar (Rita's monster creation). Perhaps this is to blame on the 2 hour duration of the film, having to try and wow viewers in such a short time, but albeit I think it was done well. The Rangers had an opportunity to show off their fighting skills and Zord abilities (mechanical animals they pilot) and bid perfect nostalgia to people like me. This fighting, accompanied by the cliché humour and poking jokes throughout the film make the latest installment of Power Rangers an enjoyable ride while it lasted.Was this a Hollywood blockbuster, primed to win multiple awards? Probably not, but was this a good introduction to a modern Power Rangers franchise? I definitely think so.Putting all biasness aside I have gone with the following score.8/10

The movie sometimes uses the Marvel template but I would say that it still manages to be fun and bold at the same time. Good one for time pass!!Because I expected too much in this movie but I had a good time pass.It delivers some useful message to children like unity, friendship, teamwork.... etc.So this movie is good for kids who want superhero movies under age 13 !!

Alright, the 2017 Power Rangers movie that half the internet was waiting for, a reboot that is based on the first season(s) of Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. After seeing the first trailer I knew that I needed to watch this movie. While friends kept saying that I shouldn't get my expectations high up. After seeing the first trailer and the first pictures of the suits, I felt it was going to be more serious than the series. Nice upgrade of the suits, while I thought that they could've made the helmets more recognizable. Anyway; seeing the movie gave me a satisfied feeling. The "stereotypes" were still intact (high school football player, cheerleader, nerdy tech guy, the daredevil etc), the diversity of ethnic backgrounds was still there like in most of the Power Rangers series. Even what I thought was lacking in the series in general, was put in the movie in a good way. A 2 hour Power Rangers movie sounded good, but I thought that the first half was going a bit too slow. You want to get to know the characters, but it was a little bit too long. The second half was better, with the final 15 minutes being really packed with action. Unfortunately the movie was pretty much over after that, but I think that a sequel would be in it's place as they can skip the introductions of the main cast and focus on the story. I didn't expect the movie to be on the action level of something like the Avengers and the MCU, but it was good. With a lot of things still not done yet, they can use a potential sequel to answer the things fans still want to see. At least I would go to a sequel of this. The main story of the Power Rangers compared to the MMPR series is pretty much in tact, the upgraded setting did pretty well, but there is room for improvement for everything. To be fair, it could've been worse. I would've rated it 6,5 but since we round the ratings, it gets a 7 from me.

Review title: An Enjoyable Modern Take On The Classic 90's Show
Review_body: Like pretty much every other kid that grew up in the 90's I watched the crap out of Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. Between the series itself and 1995's Mighty Morphin Power Rangers: The Movie, Power Rangers was a huge part of my childhood so going into this movie I was cautiously optimistic and I'm happy to say that while its not a perfect movie it completely exceeded my expectations and was for the most part a pretty good movie.The Main Cast of this movie all have fantastic chemistry with one another. The rangers them selves all deliver very good performances and we get a really good look into each of their characters. Dacre Montgomery, Naomi Scott, and RJ Tyler, who play the Red, Pink, and Blue Ranger respectively definitely stood out the most.. While the Ludi Lin and Becky G, who play the Black and Yellow Rangers, also do a great job the other 3 really get the most development out of the 5. Now one thing I always thought was funny about the original series was that the rangers were supposed to be "Teenagers with Attitude" but since at the end of the day it was a kids show the rangers were all model teen students that would routinely help with food drives and any and all other community service projects. They were basically these larger than life role models for kids to look up to, However this time around we get characters that actually feel realistic. Throughout the movie each ranger is dealing with his or her own personal issues. They're not perfect by any means, they are a group of Misfits that barely know each other and are just trying to figure out their place in the world and this approach to the characters really adds some depth to the movie. Basically if The Breakfast Club and Chronicle had a kid that movie would be Power Rangers.Supporting cast wise Elisabeth Banks does a great job as the villainous Rita Repulsa. In the series she was an over the top space witch and while the movie does make a change to her back story some of that over the top cheesiness remains and its entertaining to watch. Bryan Cranston as Zordon was decent, like Rita there are some changes to his backstory that I think worked very well and while his main purpose throughout the film is just pretty much for exposition he still gets a decent bit of character development and growth. Then finally there's Bill Hader as Alpha 5, Zordon's robot assistant. This time around Alpha has a lot more personality than he did in the original show and its definitely for the better, Hader's portrayal of Alpha reminded me a lot of K-2S0 from Star Wars Rogue One, he's very matter of fact and speaks his mind with a good amount of deadpan humor mixed in.Now I do think there were a couple of missed opportunities during the movie primarily that one of the biggest changes to the Rangers Characters is that unlike the original they are given powers that are present even when they aren't in their Ranger forms. Unfortunately though we don't really get to see these powers put to use beyond the reveal that they even exist and one or twice during the rangers training sequence. Now pacing wise the movie as fine, I didn't think it really dragged anywhere but I do think the inclusion of an unmorphed fight scene somewhere in the second act would have been a nice as it could have showcased the rangers enhanced abilities and also could have given a look into the progression of their training before the final confrontation with Rita.As far as the movies action scenes go there really isn't anything until the third act. Everything up until is basically world building and character development which I was actually very OK with, considering the fact that this is a very different take of the Power Rangers and that should this movie do well enough there are plans for five potential sequels. As I mentioned before I would have like a little more action in the movie but once the action does starts its nonstop till the end. Visually all the CGI looked great, from the Rangers in their suits fighting Rita's legion of Putties to their Zords and the eventual Megazord fight it all looked fantastic. There is a mid-credits scene that sets the stage for a sequel should this movie do well enough. So be sure to stay for that.So at the end of the day while Power Rangers isn't going to be winning any awards it was still a very entertaining movie with some great characters and a good action packed third act. If you were or still are a fan of Power Rangers you will definitely want to go see this movie and even if you're not a fan this is still a entertaining movie that's totally worth the ticket price.Check out my video review of "Power Rangers" - https://youtu.be/9QcpvwreQTw

I have to say for taking a 90's Saban tv show and turning it into a somewhat deep story line for kids and adults alike was a hard task for the production team. I think they did quite well, they have a pretty unique cast of characters for a lot of people to identify with. Anyone stating the 90's show was a ripoff they don't understand the US syndication and that it was done with permission (SMH) Back to the movie! It was awesome that they added a power ranger with autism and made alpha to be more than an aye yay yay! robot. I think it was an above standard reboot, who ever thought they would cry in power rangers movie? When I went to see this in theaters it was full of adult coming back for the nostalgia and was buzzing with energy in the room. When the credits rolled there was clapping and buzz words left and right. I hope they do make this into a series. It was cool to see the kids progress and grow and finally morph. Bad ass fight scenes and great graphics were also a great touch.

I remember watching the original as a kid and I really enjoyed this film. It was great to see what they did with the modern version of this story. I also liked how the got a diverse cast and were able to still make it about friendship and teamwork in the end. I hope the sequel is good or even better because I think there is a lot with the storyline that they can do with it.

Review_body: This is a CGI wrapped turd. The first movie from 1995 was not very good (although I liked it when I was 10). But this is way worse. The suits look crappy, the zords look like toys. the first 40 minutes or so are okay but after that it just becomes boring. Avoid this. And Hollywood, please don't make any sequels.

Review title: I feel honored to watch it!
Review_body: As a hardcore fan of the original franchise, I was expecting some teen-emo-c**p movie, and wasn't giving it a chance. After seeing it, my mind was blown away! One of the best films I've seen in decades! On few occasions didn't know what's the next thing that is going to happen, and what later happened was spot on! When I went out, I was expecting some real s**t to happen in the city, didn't felt that for a while. Really left me with fantastic impression. I'm 28 and I want to be a Power Ranger again! GO GO POWER RANGERS!

Review title: The show that got me through my youth, back with a kick!
Review_body: Wow! I had a huge smile on my face the entire film. First off I should mention I am a HUGE die-hard fan of the MMPR. I grew up in the 90's and I spent my days pretending to be a power ranger. This movie just brought back so many memories and was very emotional for me, especially with such a powerful anti-bullying message (I wish there was more of that when I was growing up!) The acting was excellent and believable, compared to a lot of other teen movies and shows this one was a big win for me. The amount of references to the franchise was very cool, and any true fan will spot them all. The updates were fantastic and needed, it got less corny and much more realistic. I laughed hard, I teared up a couple times and I had a really, really good time. Win, win win. Can't wait for the next one!
This movie is the BEST movie that I have ever seen. Dont care if it's a reboot, all I care about how much the OG power rangers have welcome the newcomers into their world.

Kids loved this one.
Pretty underrated by the looks of it from the scores.
Hope they make another one
Doesn't hold a candle to the original. The Zords don't even look like the dinosaurs the are supposed to emulate.

Review title: A completely new and AWESOME Power Rangers beginning!
Review_body: I saw lots of reviews for this movie, I guess most of those people are real Power Rangers fans. And i still can't realize: WHAT THE **** DID YOU EXPECT?!This is a REBOOT. A completely new story, just like director said. This is the first movie in a new superhero franchise, and it needs to have a focus on the story and its characters, not on battles and morphing sequences. It's made for everybody except kids, because it's dark and much more serious than the TV show which was made mostly for kids. We have five teenagers and each of them has his own issues he needs to solve himself in order to become a hero (Power Ranger) and save the world. Every next situation in the movie makes our heroes closer to each other and stronger as a team.I personally enjoyed watching this movie because it is dark, amazing, emotional, funny(of course not that much like the TV show), and has AWESOME introduction to the whole story and its main characters. I can only imagine what's planned for the sequel. CAN'T WAIT FOR THAT!!! #GO #GO #POWER #RANGERS

If you grew up watching the Power Ranger Shows and 90's Movies; do not bother, watching this version.It's meant for the trash. It's a horrible story line of how the teens came together.They have horrible acting. It's real cheesy movie for 2017. Sure the originals seemed cheesy but it was the 90's back then, but now?

Review title: Power Rangers is good for all types of fans
Review_body: Power rangers does exactly what it sets out to do. This origin story feels like a breakfast club reboot where the kids get super powers. The relationships in this movie are rarely seen in superhero movies and the actors knock their performances out of the park. All of the story feels real and the audience feels emotionally attached to these characters. The movie is very well directed by Dean Isrealite with all the CGI and background settings looking unlike the power rangers of past. The movie features star like performances from the relatively new faces of the five power rangers with Dacre Montgomery (red), Naomi Scott (pink) and RJ Cyler sticking out. Most of the story is genre defying and sets a tone for the movies to follow,However, Elizabeth banks seems to be completely over acting her entire part. Her cheesy, almost comical representation of Rita make it seem like she is in a different movie and with a completely different tone than the five power rangers along with zordon (played by Bryan Cranston). Her cheesy dialog and facial expressions bring down this movie and makes the audience think what could have been.Overall, this movie has a great amount of heart and tremendous performances from some soon to be stars that leaves the audience craving sequels to this could be great franchise, even with the miss by Elizabeth banks. Whether you were a fan of the original TV show or have no prior knowledge, people will get what they are hoping for out of this potentially massive success of a franchise.

This is not a masterpiece or an Oscar worthy piece of filmmaking. It is what it was meant to be. A retelling of a 90s era mega hit for all ages. Cheesy at times. Perhaps a little slow for children. A couple of the rangers seemed to be out of place (Black and Yellow) but all in all this was an entertaining reboot for anybody who was a fan of the Mighty Morphing Power Rangers. The movie achieves its number one goal in my opinion. It's actually entertaining. For a Power Ranger Reboot that was good enough for me.

This movie was amazing. I was hesitant at first when watching the trailers, but I just said screw it and went to go watch it with a few high school buddies of mine... And I gotta say I will never regret it. The way this movie introduced the characters was great, the story was excellent, and the action and humor was masterful to me. I grew up watching the Power Rangers series. This gave me a feeling of Nostalgia and it just made my day. Even if you are new to the series, this movie could give you an idea of what i'm talking about.
I thought it was a fun reboot. Clever and well done. Not sure why it gets so much hate.

If you go in with a great imagination you will enjoy this movie. It's a fun movie to watch. Had it's serious moments but nothing that was heart breaking. Storyline matched the older shows. Looking forward to part 2.

Review title: Coming of age story done well in a CGI fest that fans would approve.
Review_body: Power Rangers succeeds as a film that actually cares about character building, unlike the typical Transformers movie that throws you right in the middle of numbing explosions and special effects, or getting too caught up in it's lore. It is never easy to make a character driven movie for an ensemble cast, but director Dean Israelite chose to gamble a majority of the runtime on fleshing out the characters, and it pays off. We are in turn rewarded with an effective, even if somewhat flawed storyline that warms us up to the heroes and allows us to establish an emotional connection with them, from their struggles to their triumph. And the film's climax, non-stop action backed with great music, becomes a hugely rewarding payoff.Israelite, a professed fan of the series, really does get it. He uses reliable tropes of a coming of age, underdog story, and litters the film with the right amount of nostalgia and cheesiness, in all the right places. The film is ultimately funny, nostalgic and uplifting, even if predictable. Fans of the series, watch it with your friends and go in expecting nothing. You just might be overwhelmed as I was.

I loved this movie, it may not had best CGI but I node off to the writing to this movie and how they made the characters designs. I can relate to the characters and there backstory that it just hit home. And for being a fan since the first day, I'm very happy at the end result if you don't like this movie and your a fan since the beginning as well then you'll be no stranger to the comedy and weirdness/awesomeness that comes from power rangers, for blank sake they meant the teenage mutant ninja turtles But as I sat there in the theater I was just stuck watching the movie and I loved and everything about it I really hope for A lightspeed rescue

...with most movies that have Elizabeth Banks in it for more than 5 minutes, it's a stinker. I actually loved this movie until the very moment she appears. He performance is way too over the top and that's considering how ridiculous of a villain Rita was when we watched the 90s version. I think Liz is probably a great human being but there is something that happens to a movie when she's in it for too long (ex: Pitch Perfect vs. Pitch Perfect 2 & 3). Stay behind the camera, or on Press Your Luck. Everything else about this movie went exactly how it should've. It was a complete story, did feel like the budget ran thin towards the end, but they were seeing if they could jump start the franchise. Unfortunately, we may never get that Green Ranger story again, and I think it would have been told splendidly with this team.

I am a fifteen year old that has watched all the power ranger series, every single one, this was one of the greatest movies I have ever since. It was very entertaining, fast pace, and exciting. I love the movie and for all the other reviews, y'all suck, this was a great movie.

Keep it this way....POWER slip.
wasted mine time , don't dare to watch it

Review title: I liked it, took me back to childhood
Review_body: My review is going to be short. To those who always expect to see the masterpiece in every movie - please, don't. Or at least don't come here and bash with bad reviews. I understand the personal opinion, but common. This is for kids and teenagers. It promotes good virtues and friendship. It has a old-timer story with Rita and good fighting the evil with some cool Zorgs. :) It really took me back to childhood, and that cannot be a bad thing. The old Kim and Tommy at the end got me even a bit emotional. :D Just kidding, I am really not a critic and it takes for a movie to be a really big piece of s*** for me not to like it. So, maybe, my review is not going to help those who haven't seen the movie. For me, it is good. If you want to lose yourself in an imaginary world for a couple of hours, go ahead. :)
This movie is so bad. They did a terrible job with this movie. The acting is terrible and the plot is even worse.

I've really enjoyed it. Yeah it's a reboot of the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers, but I proper enjoyed it. It's different in a way from the original, but they did a really great job on making the movie look more interesting to watch. If anyone hasn't seen it yet, go and watch it when you can because it is worth the watch.

Review title: It stayed true to what it is and deserves more credit
Review_body: OK, I've seen many reviews on here bashing this movie, one review actually said they went in expecting something akin to Transformers...Well I think if that's what you're expecting then bad luck. Instead what you will be treated to is a movie with a good range of fresh actors, a well-written uplifting story, colorful action and at times slightly funny(not for lack of trying) film. You may be bewildered reading this. Some of you may call it a cheesy, unrealistic, childish pile of crap filled with teenage drama.. well guess what, this a movie remake of a 90's children's TV show about teenagers who are chosen by aliens to defend the earth with suits they can summon out of thin air and giant mech-suits they can drive into battle that are modeled after dinosaurs... its bound to be a little cheesy. That said, I didn't find there to be any unnecessary drama as all of it further developed the characters or plot.I have a lot of respect for the director and writers for staying true to the feel of the old TV show. Being a director in 2017 its much too easy to make another transformers clone with mind-numbingly stupid dialogue and boring exposition which they try (and fail) to compensate for with great action scenes. The actors are written fairly solid, though a little too charismatic for my liking, however their relationship to each other feels like a genuine friendship which could have easily been overlooked and made more "like transformers".I would gladly watch a sequel should there be one.
In my opinion, if the creators would have wanted make a film this bad, they wouldn't have succeed THIS much.

First I have to counter all the reviews complaining about how this movie is "not made for kids". 1.) Its a PG-13 rated movie (not PG) 2.) I saw it with my 8 year old, and didn't find anything wrong with it at all (especially since any of the dumb things the kids did in the movie resulted in actual consequences, so it can be great for teaching your kids life lessons). Unlike all the other movies (even PG ones) where kids do things they shouldn't and get away with it. 3.) The target audience is those of us who grew up with the power rangers (upper 25-40 year olds). Now for MY review: I'm a true rangers fan, even have all their signatures from comicons. THIS is seriously my new favorite movie! It was the most realistic movie so far out of any and all "super hero" type movies (they messed up a LOT, first mission was an epic failure, High school kids doing stupid crap actually resulted in REAL consequences...). I also enjoyed that they didn't sexualize the teens, or throw in unnecessary relationships or stupid crap.They didn't white-wash the characters (casting was PERFECT), and even added an LGBT and autistic character into the main crew without it being the focus or a limitation or some political commentary, they just were (OMG! wait for it) NORMAL PEOPLE!! THANK YOU!!It stayed true to the original rangers, but I loved that they modernized it (otherwise it really would have been super cheesy and terrible) and they gave it something new. The effects were AMAZING! I also LOVED the throwbacks they threw in there, so cool! When they said "it's morphing time" and later when the original music started playing I was dying! The 90s kid in me was nerdgasaming everywhere Dude seriously! I already want to watch it again *drool*THIS MOVIE IS AMAZING and anyone with anything bad to say is probably just some overly conservative jerk who is butthurt by the characters realistic life challenges and diversity.

I went to go see this movie with my boyfriend because he was a big fan of the show as a kid. I was not expecting to enjoy this movie at all. But within 20 minutes of the movie I was already loving every minute of it. The movie is great for all ages, it has the perfect mixture of comedy and action. This movie has honestly turned into one of my favorite movies that I have seen in the past year. I highly recommend that everyone goes and sees this movie. The acting was amazing; Becky G, Naomi Scott, Dacre Montgomery, Ludi Lin, and RJ Cyler all did amazing jobs with their roles.

Review title: Forget it's history... watch with an open mind
Review_body: So underrated. This movie was great. Its not the usual power rangers that the kids are used to in the series. This more adult oriented version may not be well received by usual fan-base because kids just want action - from start to finish - which is why I think it got such a low rating. Watch it, especially if you are a DC fan.

Review title: Unbearably hard to stay awake during the entirety of the actual movie
Review_body: The whole experience started kind of good. The first 20 minutes were mostly alright, but in my mind what the movie failed to capture as a whole was that the fact it is not the 90s anymore and even tho CGI was decent I failed to find that nostalgia feel that I was in search of when I heard the new Power Rangers movies was coming out. You do not feel anything for the characters and by the end I had felt that it was only starting to get good. It mostly feels like an elderly man tried to make something teenagers would find interesting, but the problem is, that elderly man is stuck in the last century and most of us had moved on. They forgot that kids of today couldn't care less about Power Rangers and that only people like me who used to watch the shows as a kid would be interested tho laziness added to it not being interesting and in my opinion pretty dumb. Characters are stereotypical high school kids you cannot relate too because I guess the writers couldn't bother or were afraid of any backlash had they done anything mildly interesting with them, as we see in all sorts of media today. There are certain points where you can feel what it could have been but those moments drop off pretty quickly and you find yourself either mocking scenes or plainly not caring for the characters or anything really as I did. Overall I cannot give it one star because I had paid to see it, which in my opinion is already too much for something like this, but I think had the characters been interesting as individuals and if the story hadn't felt rushed by the end it might have even been a good movie worthy of my time and nostalgia.

Review title: A great start, but the film unfortunately begins to show its faults later in the movie
Review_body: I didn't come in to this film expecting much, but I was pleasantly surprised when the film began with a very nice start. The build-up and introduction of the first few characters was very well paced and I started to become more interested in the movie, even if it was a generic "outcast is special" scenario. Unfortunately, just as I was starting to gain interest, the film started to lose its speed. As I mentioned before, the first few rangers introduced were done very well, and I even felt a bit invested in these characters. The remaining rangers, however, seemed to be awkwardly shoved into the plot. With little to no background given other then that they just happened to be in the right place at the right time with the other characters. The acting was also not that great in some areas either. Especially Dacre Montgomery as the Red ranger. Don't get me wrong, he wasn't a horrible pick for the leading ranger, he just could have done better in some moments. You can definitely pick out the times when the acting was very poor. Another thing to note is that the pacing felt off at times. The first half was set up very nicely, with good introduction to the world we were being introduced too, but what the film does wrong after that is it takes the audience's new knowledge of this world and shoves the climax of the film in our face. One second the protagonists are on their knees clearly defeated with no real answer on how to win, and then, in what feels like less than a minute or two, they're an unstoppable force that no one can defeat. My friends and I were laughing the entire duration of the climax, it was just so ridiculous and off paced we couldn't help it. Overall, not the greatest movie. I could go more in depth about the action and antagonist but that just reaffirms what I already said. I will admit that the film it had its good and funny moments, especially the first half. Go see it if you've got nothing else to do and want to laugh at some corny jokes. Otherwise I'd recommend seeing or doing something else with your free time and wait till it hits redbox.
This movie deserves a sequel. Great cast and story.

Review title: Pays Homage To What Made Power Rangers Fun For Us As Kids
Review_body: From a power rangers point of view, I think this movie was a 10 on 10. People who are interested in watching this movie, must go into the cinema with the right expectations.Please don't expect this power rangers movie to be as deep, as a movie like 'the dark knight', 'batman v superman' or 'shawshank redemption'. Historically speaking, power rangers had a corny production vibe to it, especially visually and this is one of the reasons kids fell in love with it. Kids at a young age, aren't as could as they are when they get older at interpreting deep philosophical messages; which is why power rangers in general isn't the type of show/movie you watch, expecting to leave the theater with a huge epiphany about life.I'd class this movie as overall fun and entertaining to watch. What I loved about it is the was never a scene whereby I felt bored. Though let me not exaggerate things and make you feel like every scene has got action in it, which is obviously not true. The point is the movie manages to keep an audience who walks into it with the right expectations, actively engaged in it.The were moral lessons one can learn by watching the movie. Issues like how to work as a team, how to be a leader, human mortality, opening yourself up emotionally to your friends, resisting conforming to societal expectations and having an open mindset.A few downsides to this movie were the graphics kind of looked cheap -- as in the visual effects weren't as real-like, like a movie like star wars the force awakens in my opinion. The villain came off as corny and audiences who like serious movies, probably won't like this movie. Though keep in mind -- the cheap looking graphics, corny villain and sometimes lack of seriousness in this movie is what makes power rangers the franchise it is today.So don't go into the theater expecting a movie with extremely deep philosophical points, that tells us humans are ultimately self-serving individuals etc.

I like this movie a lot like any other SuperHero movies (I think because I'm a marvel fan) and I was born with the very first franchise series, I've been watching this after every season that I finished like a long marathon until the next Movie arrive (Ha if it arrives) but I think it will maybe, and this Movie keeps me alive and my dreams.

This is coming from an old Power Rangers fan: Despite all the negative reviews the movie is fun from start to finish. Movies like this have a tendency to put out boring one dimensional characters.Where the Power Rangers really shines is presenting us with actual people who deal with actual problems. A lot of people outright hate the movie for not putting in much action but the end fight is worth it.Not spoiling anything but i would like my action scene to be well earned.An area in which this movie doesn't falter.By the end you will know(not only see) these characters and when they are put into zord fights you will care for them.UNLIKE THE TV SHOW. And i have to say character development scenes in this movie aren't boring and there isn't much exposition. On a side note: THE LAST FIGHT WAS EPIC.

This was the first movie that I went to go see in theaters as a kid with my parents. To relive this moment once again was just amazing and to be right there in the moment as I was 20 years ago I was fairly pleased. It truly tied in with the original Power Rangers TV series and I cannot wait to see what is in store for this rebooted installment.

I am 50 years old and did not watch the original TV series. I found this movie to be excellent! It was funny, the actors were perfectly cast, the story lines were well done, and the action and special effects were amazing. What more could anyone want? If you are looking for something that is a serious representation of today's life, then this is not the show for you. If, however, you are looking for pure fun that will make you laugh, go see Power Rangers!

Nice adaptation from the TV series Power Rangers Dino Thunder. Different story. Visual effects great. Wating for next part. As always I like the red ranger the most. It's a watchable movie. This movie is a family entertainer. Kids will love this movie. All rangers acting not bad. I wish next part will be much better than this one. The climax scene was visual treat and at the end funny.

Review title: Fun Movie to Relax and Watch
Review_body: I never watched the original series nor had any knowledge beyond the fact that there are rangers that fight some sort of crime, so I came into this would no expectations.The movie had a good cast - the five main stars all being relatively new to acting with few credits to their name - with supporting roles from Elizabeth Banks, Bryan Cranston, and Bill Hader.The script could have been better, but the cast did a great job with what they had. Overall there were some really cliché lines and some that were even a little cringey.What made the movie good however, is that you can relax, have a good time, and not take it seriously. Have a laugh, enjoy the action.With all the ways this project could have gone wrong, the team behind it did a remarkable job returning with this. So the harsh reviews aren't necessary. It's tough to make a film like this perfect when there's a lot of criticism and lore affecting how it's made.

When I saw the movie, I was blown away. Every "Power Rangers" movie was a gem. This one was no exception. Elizabeth Banks was cast perfectly. She gave the role of Rita Repulsa another dimension. The way Goldar was created from actual gold was genius! I couldn't think of a better way to recreate such an iconic character. However, the Ranger suits, Zordon and Alpha 5's designs were a bit disappointing, which is why I gave this film a 6. If you do a reboot, at least try to keep the original aesthetics!

When I saw the trailers for the movie my initial thoughts were that it was cool they were making a Power Rangers movie but the music was horrible, the CGI was just bad, and the alien power ranger suits that reminded me of Venom from Spider Man 3. This initial reaction kept me away from seeing it in theaters. However now that its available to watch digitally I thought I'd give it a watch and damn was I in for a surprise.So spoiler alert, if you went into this movie wanting non-stop action then you were probably disappointed. This movie follows the formula most first movies in the superhero genre. Unlike the sequels where the heroes have their powers you need to spend time on getting to know the characters, how they get their powers and in this case how they come together to form the bond that leads them to become a true team. After they form the bond and get used to their powers they face the enemy that has been gathering power throughout the film and end up saving the day and proving themselves as heroes to the town. And I liked how they implemented it in this film.The suits ended up not being too bad. They explained the suits well enough and they grew on me after watching the film. The one thing I wasn't a fan of was Goldar...instead of a monkey creature wearing gold armor you literally got walking liquid gold. Ummm...yeah. Granted the monkey wearing the gold suit makes even less sense but I dunno seeing the zords fighting the liquid gold monster just didn't look right. As far as the zords themselves go they were decent enough. The designs were alright. I liked how they interacted with each other and helped each other out but the CGI was almost as bad as the original power rangers movie with the ninja zords. I don't mind CGI when its done right but this missed the mark a little.So overall not a bad movie. Its not going to win an Oscar anytime soon but I definitely can see a sequel happening. I liked the cast and thought most of the actors did a decent job. My gripes are not with the story, which I thought was pretty dang good. I just wish that if the production team was aiming for a more realistic version of power rangers they would have put a little more effort into making the visuals more realistic. Instead you got a serious movie with passable CGI at best. If they were going for a campy movie than we would have been than happy with a man in a mech suit. And stick with more remixes of the power rangers theme next time and drop whatever crap they had playing during the finale. Seriously is anyone going to be playing that song back in 10 years???

Review title: It is so NOT what I expected
Review_body: When the first time I saw the trailer, I really hoped that I would bring back my childhood memories where the series was full of friendship and actions. After watching it though, I got really disappointed as *SPOILER* it lost a lot of actions. Instead, it was boring because of *SPOILER* forced background stories. *SPOILER* It took more than half way the movie to make the Rangers morph into their costume, and it took a lot more to change into the Megaforce (or what so ever).It surely is not the best Power Rangers I've ever seen.

Review title: A truly great nostalgia ride with a modern twist
Review_body: It maybe the 6 year old in me but boy does this film rock, some fantastic nods to the past but brought forward to 2017. RJ Cyler (Billy, Blue Ranger) is outstanding, all the performances were great.Nice little cameo from a few old Rangers at the end.Go and see it if you had a love of this as a kid, it will not disappoint.

The movie was at best a OK to watch. I was a fan of Power Rangers as a kid and it saddens me that this "effort", even though I don't think anyone tried really hard, to reboot the series was so bad. The one thing I can give to this movie is the CGI. I really like those and they were pretty damn well in my opinion, even though Alpha was... weird and Zordon in the wall, well... I have one of those things decorating my room. And I don't even like it. Plot wasn't there, script wasn't there, music was kinda there, but not really, and acting... Man I'm sad. I have to admit though that the one thing that really pushed me to write this "bad" review is the fact that I kept hearing a bunch of teenagers, that happened to be the Power Rangers, say "kill" all the time. Really script writer/director? You liked that? Turning heroes into murderers by using only one word? And repeatedly too! What happened to the word "stop"? Couldn't you just say "We have to STOP her"? Always kill, kill, KILL! And the "FINAL BATTLE"? What a letdown. A almost 2-hour movie to see the bad gal get b-slapped into space? OK I have to admit that was pretty funny and the reason I gave this a 3 star instead of 2. The 2nd star was for the CG. Man... Did I say I am sad?

Review title: Just what I was looking for
Review_body: I remember watching the trailer for this movie and thinking how cheesy it looked. 5 teenagers with teenager dramas and no real plot. After watching I can say its is exactly that! Let's be honest here, power rangers were a crap series. Yes we all loved it as kids, but it was just a way to sell toys to kids. But this movie takes all those rotten lemons and make a pretty average lemonade. There is a great mix of action and comedy, and even if some parts dragged on, it really get that teenager feeling. The ending is more focused on the action part. I'm sure it would work better if they made the part with the zords shorters because they just didn't have a good enough CGI animation.

I went into the movie with relatively middling expectations. I mean, it's a Power Rangers movie, and I could only expect so much quality to go into it. However, I came out of the theater very surprised how much I enjoyed it.Each of the five leads really brought their a-game and were believable in their portrayals of each character. Each Ranger even got their own moment of sentimental depth. Also, each Ranger truly is a "teenager with attitude", as opposed to the original Mighty Morphin' team. For example, Jason (Dacre Montgomery) was a star football player who played a prank that cost him scholarship offers and also causes him to be placed under house arrest.I was especially surprised (and impressed) with the direction they took Rita Repulsa (Elizabeth Banks). Rather than being the flamboyant, loud-mouthed interpretation that the fans have known her to be, she is portrayed as a power (and gold) hungry psychopath who has genuine shades of horror to her.Zordon (Bryan Cranston) was fleshed out as a lot more than just a giant face on a screen. The film gives him a truly engrossing back story that connects him with Rita.There was even a scene early on that reveals that Billy (RJ Cyler) is autistic, but the film didn't make a huge deal out of it, which, honestly, is the best way to go about it. Things like this aren't supposed to be taken as a huge reveal, as there's a good chance that you know a few autistic people in your life and don't even realize it.They do something similar with Trini (Becky G), except rather reveal her as autistic, she is revealed as gay. The team doesn't make a big deal about it, and accept that she's different. Bravo to the writing team for that.In the end, I was really impressed with Power Rangers. I didn't grow up with the franchise (I saw the original series when I was a young teen), but I'm genuinely excited for the many sequels planned.

This could have been an awesome summer blockbuster. It just fails on so many levels. I'm not a 90's kid and I didn't grow up watching power rangers. I went into this movie with an open mind and expecting a sci-fi/fantasy action type of film.. something exciting and fun.. or at least a decent popcorn flick, if nothing else. That's not what I got! It's just plain bad. There were problems all over this movie, but I'll try to address the main issues i had with it:1. Boring - It just felt like it lagged on an on, I kept waiting for the action to begin and it didn't come literally until the last 15 minutes of the movie. It was basically like a teen drama that you'd see on Mtv or the CW... they didn't even turn into power rangers or use any of their robots until the very end. Their megazord reminded me of something off the last Transformers movie.2. Mediocre Production - The little amount of action that finally came was poorly executed (boring action, if you know what I mean) and there was a lot of atrocious looking CGI. Think about the quality of CGI you might see on a TV show, because they don't have the budget of a major film... It's like that, but a little worse. The whole plot is dumb.
